main event: On 28 April 1949, in Homer, Michigan, a civilian observer reported sighting six silver disc-shaped objects rotating around in a wide circle at an estimated altitude of 300 to 1000 feet. The objects were traveling at about 100 miles per hour and disappeared over the treetops while heading west. Initially, the observer mistook the objects for sea gulls.
interesting points: The observer reported seeing six silver disc-shaped objects rotating in a wide circle at an estimated altitude of 300 to 1000 feet, traveling at about 100 miles per hour.
The objects were described as revolving around as if they were attached to an axle, indicating a unique and specific type of movement.
Two other employees from the Pet Milk Co. also reported sighting six flying discs over Howell, Michigan, and pursued them in an automobile for about five miles.
The newspaper clipping from the Detroit Free Press reported two individuals pursuing the flying discs in an automobile for about five miles before losing sight of them.
After the observation, the witness informed a local newspaper correspondent and the editor about the experience, indicating a proactive effort to report the incident to the media.
witnesses: civilian observer, two employees of the Pet Milk Co.
